articles.title: Salesforce CEO Marc Benioff: This isnâ€™t our first SaaSpocalypse
articles.author: Julie Bort
articles.content:
Salesforce pulled out all the stops to convince investors that the AI revolution wonâ€™t be its death when itannouncedfourth-quarter earnings on Wednesday.

Salesforce reported a solid quarter of $10.7 billion in revenue, up 13% year-over-year. For the year, it reported $41.5 billion in revenue, up 10% over the previous year, with both results boosted by its $8 billion acquisition ofdata management companyInformaticalast May.

Net income landed at $7.46 billion, and the company offered strong guidance for the year ahead, projecting revenue of $45.8 billion to $46.2 billion â€” a 10% to 11% increase. It also said its â€œremaining performance obligation,â€ or RPO, is over $72 billion. Thatâ€™s a figure that shows revenue under contact that has not yet been delivered or recognized as earned revenue.

The numbers, though, could only do so much. Software-as-a-service stocks, withSalesforce as their poster child, have been getting hammered lately. Investors fear the rise of AI agents will undermine these companies, making their per-employee-seatbusiness models obsolete. The situation has been dubbed the â€œSaaSpocalypse.â€

The concept hung so heavily in the air during the earnings call that CEO Marc Benioff mentioned the term at least six times.

â€œYouâ€™ve heard about the SaaSpocalypse? And it isnâ€™t our first. Weâ€™ve had a few of them,â€ he said, later adding, â€œIf there is a SaaSpocalypse, it may be eaten by the Sasquatch because there are a lot of companies using a lot of SaaS because it just got better with agents.â€

In an attempt to convince the world of its continued health, Salesforce threw everything and the kitchen sink into this earnings report. The company increased its dividend by nearly 6% to $0.44 per share. It launched a new $50 billion share buyback program. Thatâ€™s always a favorite with shareholders because it both creates a sturdy buyer of shares and reduces the number of shares in circulation (which can boost the stock price).

The company also revamped the earnings call itself. It was part podcast, part infomercial, and part normal Q&A with a few questions from Wall Street analysts.

Instead of running through the numbers, Benioff interviewed three Salesforce customers on camera to testify to their love of its new agentic options: the CEO of home appliance company SharkNinja; the CEO of Wyndham Hotels and Resorts; and, just to hammer the point, the CEO of SaaStr, the software industry conference and media company. Weâ€™ll truncate the interviews to the shortest summary: They all love Salesforceâ€™s AI agent products.

Salesforce also introduced a new metric for its agentic products: agentic work units (â€œAWUâ€). The idea here is that instead of simply counting â€œtokensâ€ â€” the standard unit of AI processing volume â€” AWU attempts to measure something more meaningful: whether an agent actually completed a task. (Salesforce logged 19 trillion tokens last quarter, which sounds like a lot but reallyis notin the AI world.)

â€œYou can ask it a question and it can write you a poem, but thatâ€™s not really all that valuable in the enterprise world,â€ Salesforce president and CMO Patrick Stokes said on the call. So AWU is intended to measure when the agent writes to a record or does some other verifiable piece of work.

On top of that, Salesforce also presented its own architectural vision of the coming world of agents. It shows SaaS software like itselfowning most of the tech stack, with the AI model makers on the bottom as unseen, interchangeable, and commoditized work engines.

This was a direct counter to one of the causes of a SaaSpocalypse sell-off earlier this month, afterOpenAI released its enterprise agent, Frontier. OpenAIâ€™s architectural vision shows OpenAI owning most of the stack, with systems-of-record SaaS providers (the databases and business-software platforms where companies store their core data)on the bottom as the unseen engines.

And if all that wasnâ€™t enough to influence investors: Benioff was dressed in a black leather jacket, echoing the signature look of the CEO clearly crushing it in the AI world: Nvidiaâ€™s Jensen Huang.

Salesforce reported a solid quarter of $10.7 billion in revenue, up 13% year-over-year. For the year, it reported $41.5 billion in revenue, up 10

articles.title: Nvidia has another record quarter amid record capex spends
articles.author: Russell Brandom
articles.content:
Chip giant and worldâ€™s most valuable company Nvidia reportedrecord profitsin its most recent quarter on Wednesday, as demand for AI compute continues to skyrocket.

â€œThe demand for tokens in the world has gone completely exponential,â€ CEO Jensen Huang said on a call with analysts following the results. â€œI think weâ€™re all seeing that, to the point where even our six-year-old GPUs in the cloud are completely consumed and the pricing is going up.â€

The company reported $68 billion in revenue in the most recent quarter, up 73% from the prior year, with $62 billion of that revenue coming from the companyâ€™s data center business.

Notably, Nvidia divided the data center revenue into $51 billion in compute revenue (largely GPUs) and $11 billion in networking products like NVLink. The company reported $215 billion in revenue for the full year.

As in previous quarters, the company did not report any revenue from chip exports to China, despite the recent lifting of export restrictions by the U.S. government. â€œWhile small amounts of H200 products for China-based customers were approved by the U.S. government, they have yet to generate any revenue, and we do not know whether any imports will be allowed into China,â€ Colette Kress, the companyâ€™s chief financial officer, said.

â€œOur competitors in China, bolstered by recent IPOs, are making progress,â€ she continued, in an apparent reference toMoore Threadsâ€™ IPO in December, â€œand have the potential to disrupt the structure of the global AI industry over the long term.â€

During the investor call, Huang also addressed the companyâ€™s pending investment in OpenAI, which has beenreported at $30 billion.

â€œWe continue to work with OpenAI toward a partnership agreement. We believe we are close,â€ Huang said. He also referenced partnerships with Anthropic, Meta, and Elon Muskâ€™s xAI. However,statements Nvidia filedwith the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission on Wednesday emphasized that there was â€œno assuranceâ€ an investment would take place.

Huang also addressed concerns about the sustainability oftech companiesâ€™ capex commitments, saying he believed the compute investments would soon bring revenue.

â€œIn this new world of AI, computeisrevenue. Without compute, thereâ€™s no way to generate tokens. Without tokens, thereâ€™s no way to grow revenues,â€ Huang said. â€œWeâ€™ve reached the inflection point and weâ€™re generating profitable tokens that are productive for customers and profitable for the cloud service providersâ€

articles.title: Anthropic acquires computer-use AI startup Vercept after Meta poached one of its founders
articles.author: Julie Bort
articles.content:
Anthropic on Wednesdayannouncedthat it has acquired Vercept, an AI startup with deep roots to some of the biggest names in Seattleâ€™s tech scene. The acquisition marks the latest after Anthropicacquired coding agent engine Bunin December to help scale Claude Code.

Vercept had created tools for more complex agentic tasks, including its product Vy, a computer-use agent in the cloud that could operate a remote Apple MacBook. Vercept is one of the many startups working on re-imagining the personal computer for the age of AI agents. As part of the deal, Anthropic is shuttering Verceptâ€™s product on March 25.

The startup was a grad of Seattleâ€™s AI-focusedincubatorAI2,which spawned from the longstanding Allen Institute for AI. Verceptâ€™s co-founders had roots with the Allen Institute, as well, and were previously researchers there. One co-founder, Matt Deitke, made news last year as one of the AI researcherswho negotiated a monster $250 million salaryfrom Meta to join its Superintelligence Lab. On Wednesday, Deitke congratulated his former colleaguesin a post on X.

Congrats to@ehsanik,@LucaWeihs, and@inkynumbers!Happy for you all :) ğŸš€https://t.co/n3WTq4CAAs

Vercept was a relatively high-profile AI startup in the region. In aLinkedIn postannouncing the acquisition by Anthropic, Vercept CEO Kiana Ehsani said the startup had raised a total of $50 million. She called out Fifty Yearsâ€™ Seth Bannon, a board member, as the lead investor. Vercept previously announced it had raised a$16 million seed roundlast January.

The list of angel investors was impressive, too, and included former Google CEO Eric Schmidt, Google DeepMind chief scientist Jeff Dean, Cruise founder Kyle Vogt, and Dropbox co-founder Arash Ferdowsi,GeekWire reported.

In Anthropicâ€™s announcement of the acquisition, the company named co-founders Ehsani, Luca Weihs, and Ross Girshick as some of the team brought on to join Anthropic in the acquisition. However, not all of Verceptâ€™s co-founders are joining the Claude maker.

Oren Etzioni, who haspreviously been namedas a co-founder of Vercept and investor in the startup, is well known in Seattle as the founding leader of the Allen Institute for AI. Along with Deitke, he is also not joining Anthropic, and was vocally less pleased about the acqui-hire. He postedon LinkedIn: â€œAfter a little bit more than a year,Verceptis throwing in the towel and giving their customers 30 days to get off the platform. Sad. A fantastic team is joining Anthropic. I wish them the very best!â€

Etzioni is also a professor at the University of Washington and known forother startupsheâ€™s founded and backed as a VC. He did not respond to a request for comment.

On Etzioniâ€™s LinkedIn post, he accused Bannon, the Vercept lead investor, of being â€œpartly responsibleâ€ for Vercept not hiring the correct business people. A back and forth ensued between the investors, withBannon condemningEtzioniâ€™s remarks: â€œâ€¦ you disparaged the heroic work of the founders for achieving an outcome most could only dream of,â€ Bannon replied in the LinkedIn string. They also accused each other of other less savory things like lying and legal threats.

While public spats between investors are entertaining, and essentially meaningless, the underlying motivation is notable. The stakes are high to build the next big AI winner, and now a promising startup that raised a decently sized war chest will be tucked into Anthropic.

While the terms of the deal were not disclosed, Etzioni says he got a return on his money. Anthropic clearly wanted these researchers (perhaps â€” especially â€” with another of them at Meta).

Still, Etzioni told GeekWire that he remains bummed. â€œIâ€™m pleased to have gotten a positive return but obviously disappointed that after just a little over a year with so much traction, and such a fantastic team, weâ€™re basically throwing in the towel,â€ he said.

The founders joining Anthropic, however, appear happy, according to CEOâ€™s Ehsaniâ€™s LinkedIn post. â€œThe choices were clear: we could build independently and work toward the same vision as two separate versions of it, or join forces with an incredible team and accelerate that vision into reality. The decision became an easy choice,â€ she said of joining Anthropic.

Correction: Steve Bannon is a VC with Fifty Years, not AI2. The story has been corrected and we apologize for the error.
articles.excerpt:
Anthropic on Wednesdayannouncedthat it has acquired Vercept, an AI startup with deep roots to some of the biggest names in Seattleâ€™s tech scene. The acquisition marks the latest after Anthropicacquired coding agent engine Bunin December to help scale Claude Code.

Vercept had created tools for more

articles.title: Inside the story of the US defense contractor who leaked hacking tools to Russia
articles.author: Lorenzo Franceschi-Bicchierai
articles.content:
A veteran cybersecurity executive who prosecutors said â€œbetrayedâ€ the United States will spend at least the next seven years behind bars, after pleading guilty to stealing and selling hacking and surveillance tools to a Russian firm.

Peter Williams, a former executive at U.S. defense contractor L3Harris,was sentenced on Tuesday to 87 months in prisonfor leaking his former companyâ€™s trade secrets in exchange for $1.3 million in crypto between 2022 and 2025. Williams sold the exploits to Operation Zero, which the U.S. government calls â€œone of the worldâ€™s most nefarious exploit brokers.â€

The successful conviction of Williams follows one of the most high-profile leaks of sensitive Western-made hacking tools in recent years. Even now that the case is over, there are still unanswered questions.

Williams, a 39-year-old Australian citizen who resided in Washington, D.C., was the general manager of Trenchant, the division of L3Harris that develops hacking and surveillance tools for the U.S. government and its closest global intelligence partners. Prosecutors sayWilliams took advantage of having â€œfull accessâ€ to the companyâ€™s secure networksto download the hacking tools onto a portable hard drive, and later to his computer. Williams contacted Operation Zero under a pseudonym though, so itâ€™s unclear if Operation Zero ever knew Williamsâ€™ real identity.

Trenchant is a crew of hackers and bug hunters who dig deep into other popular software made by companies like Google and Apple, identify flaws in those millions of lines of code, then devise techniques to turn those flaws into workable exploits that can be used to reliably hack into those products. These tools are typically calledzero-dayexploits because they take advantage of software flaws unknown to its developer, whichcan be worth millions of dollars.

TheU.S. Department of Justice allegedthat the hacking tools Williams sold could have allowed whoever used them to â€œpotentially access millions of computers and devices around the world.â€

For the past few months, I have been talking to sources and reporting on Williamsâ€™ story before news broke thathe had been arrested. But what I had heard was patchwork and at times conflicting. I had heard someone had been arrested, but given the secret nature of the work involved in exploit development, proving it would be challenging.

Contact UsDo you have more information about this case, and the alleged leak of Trenchant hacking tools? From a non-work device, you can contact Lorenzo Franceschi-Bicchierai securely on Signal at +1 917 257 1382, or via Telegram, Keybase and Wire @lorenzofb, orby email.

When I first heard of Williams, I wasnâ€™t clear that I had even gotten his name right. At that point, his story was a rumor, moving through the hush-hush grapevine of zero-day exploit developers, sellers, and people with ties to the intelligence community.

I heard that maybe he was called John, or perhaps Duggan? Or all the different ways you can spell that in English.

Some of the first rumors I heard were contradictory. Apparently he stole zero-days from Trenchant, and maybe he sold them to Russia, or perhaps another enemy of the United States and its allies, like North Korea or China?

It took weeks just to confirm that there was indeed someone who even fit that description. (It turned out that Williamsâ€™ middle name is John, and Doogie is his nickname in hacker circles.)

Then, as the weeks of reporting rolled on, things started to become much clearer.

AsI first revealed in October, Trenchant fired an employee after Williams, who was still at the time head of Trenchant, accused the employee of stealing and leaking Chrome zero-days. The story was even more intriguing because the employee told me that after he was fired,Â Apple notified him that someone had targeted his personal iPhone.

What I learned was just the tip of the iceberg. I had heard more from my sources, but we were still piecing parts of the story together.

Soon after, prosecutors made their first formal accusation against a man named Peter Williams for stealing trade secrets, which first surfaced in the U.S. public court system. In that first court document, prosecutors confirmed that the buyer of these trade secrets was a buyer in Russia.

However, there was no explicit reference to L3Harris nor Trenchant, nor the fact that the trade secrets that Williams stole were zero-days. Crucially, we still couldnâ€™t confirm for certain that it was the same Peter Williams, who we thought would have access to highly sensitive exploits as Trenchantâ€™s boss, and not some terrible case of mistaken identity.

Westillwerenâ€™t there.

On a hunch and with nothing to lose, we contacted the Department of Justice to ask if they would confirm that the person in the document was in fact Peter Williams, the former boss of L3Harris Trenchant. A spokesperson confirmed.

Finally,the story was out. A week later, Williams pleaded guilty.

When I first heard of his story, while I trusted my sources, I remained skeptical. Why would someone like Williams do what the rumors claimed? But he did, and did so for money, prosecutors allege, which Williams then used to buy a house, jewelry, and luxury watches.

It was a remarkable fall from grace for Williams, once seen as an accomplished and brilliant hacker, and especially for someone who previously worked at Australiaâ€™s top foreign spy agency and served in the countryâ€™s military.

We still donâ€™t know specifically which exploits and hacking tools Williams stole and sold. Trenchant estimated a loss of $35 million, per court documents. But Williamsâ€™ lawyers said the stolen tools were not classified as a government secret.

We can glean some insight based on the circumstances of the case.

Given that the Justice Department said the stolen tools could be used to hack â€œmillions of computers and devices,â€ itâ€™s likely the tools refer to zero-days in popular consumer software, such as Android devices, Appleâ€™s iPhones and iPads, and web browsers.

There is some evidence pointing in their direction. During a hearing last year, prosecutors read out louda post published on Xby Operation Zero,according to independent cybersecurity reporter Kim Zetter, who attended the hearing.

â€œDue to high demand on the market, weâ€™re increasing payouts for top-tier mobile exploits,â€ read the post, which specifically mentioned Android and iOS. â€œAs always, the end user is a non-NATO country.â€

Operation Zerooffers millions of dollarsfor details of security vulnerabilities in Android devices and iPhones, messaging appslike Telegram, as well asother kinds of software, such as Microsoft Windows, and hardware vendors, such as several brands of servers and routers.

Operation Zeroclaimsto work with the Russian government. At the time Williams sold the exploits to the Russian broker, Putinâ€™s full-scale invasion of Ukraine was already underway.

On the same day that Williams was sentenced, the U.S. Treasuryannounced it had imposed sanctionsagainst Operation Zero and its founder Sergey Zelenyuk, calling the company a national security threat. This was the governmentâ€™s first confirmation that Williams had sold the exploits to Operation Zero.

In its statement, the Treasury said the broker â€œsold those stolen tools to at least one unauthorized user.â€ At this point we donâ€™t know who this user is. The user could be a foreign intelligence service, or it could be a ransomware gang, given that the Treasury also sanctioned Oleg Vyacheslavovich Kucherov, an alleged member of the Trickbot gang, who also allegedly worked with Operation Zero.

In a court document, prosecutors said that L3Harris was able to figure out that â€œan unauthorized vendor was selling a componentâ€ of one of the stolen trade secrets â€œby comparing company-specific vendor data found on a stolen component that matched.â€

Prosecutors also said that Williams â€œrecognized code he wrote and soldâ€ to Operation Zero â€œbeing utilized by a South Korean broker,â€ further suggesting that both L3Harris and prosecutors know which tools were stolen and sold to Operation Zero.

Another unanswered question is: Did anyone, either the U.S. government or L3Harris, alert Apple, Google, or whichever tech companyâ€™s products were affected by the zero-day flaws, now that the exploits had leaked?

Any company or developer would want to know that someone could have used (or could still use) a zero-day against their users and customers so that they can patch the flaws as soon as possible. And at this point, the zero-days are of no use for L3Harris and its government customers.

When I asked Apple and Google, neither company responded to my inquiries. L3Harris did not respond either.

Then thereâ€™s the mystery of the scapegoat, who was fired after Williams accused him of stealing and leaking code.

At sentencing, Justice Department prosecutorsconfirmedthat the employee was fired, saying Williams â€œstood idly by while another employee of the company was essentially blamed for [his] own conduct.â€ In response, Williamsâ€™ attorney rebuffed prosecutors, claiming that the former employee â€œwas fired for misconduct,â€ citing claims of dual-employment and improper handling of the companyâ€™s intellectual property.

According to a court document submitted by Williamsâ€™ lawyers, as part of the L3Harris internal investigation, the company placed the employee on leave, seized his devices, transferred them to the U.S., and â€œoffered them to the FBI.â€

When reached for comment, an unnamed FBI spokesperson said the bureau had nothing to add apart from the Justice Departmentâ€™spress release.

After being fired, that employee, whom we identified with the alias Jay Gibson, received a notification from Apple that his personal iPhone was targeted â€œwith a mercenary spyware attack.â€

Applesendsthesenotificationsto users it thinks were the target of attacks using tools like those made by NSO Group or Intellexa.

Who tried to hack Gibson? He received the notification on March 5, 2025, more than six months after the FBI investigation had begun. The FBI â€œregularly interacted with [Williams] in late 2024 through the summer of 2025,â€according to a court document.

Given the nature of the leaked tools, it is plausible that the FBI, or perhaps even a U.S. intelligence agency, targeted Gibson as part of the investigation into Williamsâ€™ leaks. But we just donâ€™t know, and thereâ€™s a chance that neither the public, nor Gibson, will ever find out.

Updated to clarify 22nd paragraph attributing the toolsâ€™ lack of classification to Williamsâ€™ lawyers.
articles.excerpt:
A veteran cybersecurity executive who prosecutors said â€œbetrayedâ€ the United States will spend at least the next seven years behind bars, after pleading guilty to stealing and selling hacking and surveillance tools to a Russian firm.

Peter Williams, a former executive at U.S. defense contractor L3H

articles.title: Alphabet-owned robotics software company Intrinsic joins Google
articles.author: Rebecca Szkutak
articles.content:
Google is moving further into physical AI by bringing a familiar robotics software platform under its wing.

Alphabet-owned Intrinsic, which builds AI models and software designed to make industrial robots more accessible, is joining Google, the companiesannounced on Wednesday. Intrinsic will remain a distinct entity within Google but will work closely with Google DeepMind and will tap into Googleâ€™s Gemini AI models and cloud services.

Alphabet declined to share information regarding funding or purchase price.

Intrinsic â€œgraduatedâ€ into anindependent Alphabet-owned company in 2021after five years of development within Alphabetâ€™s X, the companyâ€™s moonshot research division. Other companies that have graduated from X include robotaxi company Waymo and drone delivery company Wing.

Wendy Tan White has served as Intrinsicâ€™s CEO since its spinout in 2021.

The company hit the ground running. A few months after announcing its independence,Intrinsic acquired Vicarious, a fellow robotics software company, in April 2022. While the purchase price wasnâ€™t disclosed, Vicarious had raised about $250 million from VCs and tech bigwigs like Jeff Bezos.

A few months later, Intrinsicacquired several for-profit divisionsof Open Robotics, a nonprofit organization that builds hardware and software platforms for the robotics industry.

Despite this rapid expansion,Intrinsic laid off 20% of its workforcein January 2023.

The company announced its first product, Flowstate, just a few months later. Flowstate is a software platform fordeveloping robotics workflowsaimed at developers that donâ€™t have deep robotics experience â€” aligning with the companyâ€™s mission to make robotics more accessible.

Since then, the company has fine-tuned the technology, improved its simulation capabilities, and released its Intrinsic Vision AI model in late 2025.

Intrinsic announced ajoint venture with electronics manufacturer Foxconnin October 2025 that entails the two companies working together on general-purpose intelligent robots to transform how electronics are manufactured, with the goal of full factory automation.

Now, the company is working toward those goals with closer collaboration with Googleâ€™s AI prowess.

â€œCombined with Googleâ€™s incredible AI and infrastructure, weâ€™re going to unlock the promise of physical AI for a much broader set of manufacturing businesses and developers. This will fundamentally shift production, from its economics to operations, and enable truly advanced manufacturing,â€ Tan White wrote in the companyâ€™s blog post.

This move makes a lot of sense for Google, as many tech leaders, includingNvidiaâ€™s Jensen HuangandQualcommâ€™s Cristiano Amon, see physical AI as the next natural step in the monetization and advancement of AI models and technology.

Google is moving further into physical AI by bringing a familiar robotics software platform under its wing.

Alphabet-owned Intrinsic, which builds AI models and software designed to make industrial robots more accessible, is joining Google, the companiesannounced on Wednesday. Intrinsic will remain

articles.title: The White House wants AI companies to cover rate hikes. Most have already said they would.
articles.author: Tim Fernholz
articles.content:
The proliferation of AI data centers plugging into the national electrical grid has helped increase consumer electricity prices, driving up the average national electricity price by more than 6% in the last year.

Thatâ€™s not a good look for the incumbents ahead of this fallâ€™s elections, and President Donald Trump addressed the challenge in his State of the Union speech last night.

â€œWeâ€™re telling the major tech companies that they have the obligation to provide for their own power needs,â€ Trump said. â€œThey can build their own power plants as part of their factory, so that no oneâ€™s prices will go up.â€

The  hyperscalers in question donâ€™t need to be told. They have already made public commitments in recent weeks to cover electricity costs by building their own power sources, paying higher rates, or both, part of a broader effort to solve PR problems around data center expansion and win over skeptical communities.

On January 11, Microsoftannouncedits policy â€œto ensure that the electricity cost of serving our datacenters is not passed on to residential customers.â€ On January 26, OpenAIcommittedto â€œpaying its own way on energy, so that our operations donâ€™t increase your energy prices.â€ On February 11, Anthropic made thesame pledgeto â€œcover electricity price increases that consumers face from our data centers.â€ Yesterday, Googleannouncedthe largest battery project in the world to support a data center in Minnesota.

What these commitments mean in practice, and who will determine which data centers are responsible for which price increases, remains unknown. The White House has not released the text of the proposed pledge.

â€œA handshake agreement with Big Tech over data center costs isnâ€™t good enough,â€ Arizona Democratic Senator Mark Kellysaidon social media. â€œAmericans need a guarantee that energy prices wonâ€™t soar and communities have a say.â€

White House spokesperson Taylor Rodgerssaidthat next week, companies will send representatives to formally sign the pledge at the White House. Amazon, Google, Meta, Microsoft, xAI, Oracle, and OpenAI are reportedly among those set to attend. However, none of the companies have confirmed their attendance.

Even if tech companies commit to taking on electricity costs, on-site power plants may not be a panacea â€” they can still have adverse impacts on thesurrounding environment, and will stress supply chains for natural gas, turbines, photovoltaics, and batteries, depending on how companies aim to power their compute.

FromÂ October 13â€“15 at Moscone WestÂ in San Francisco, 10,000+ founders, operators, and investors gather for three days ofÂ high-signal conversations, deal-making, and actionable insights.Â DisruptÂ isÂ not just contentÂ â€”Â itâ€™sÂ access to acceleratedÂ growth.

articles.title: US cybersecurity agency CISA reportedly in dire shape amid Trump cuts and layoffs
articles.author: Zack Whittaker
articles.content:
U.S. cybersecurity agencyCISAisreportedly in dire shape, according to bipartisan lawmakers and industry leaders who fear that the agencyâ€™s ability to perform its core mission has been diminished and left it unprepared for a cybersecurity crisis.

News siteCyberscoopâ€™sTim Starks spoke with sources across Congress, the private cyber industry, and beyond, and what came back reflected a general consensus that CISA has suffered under cuts and layoffs during the Trump administrationâ€™s first year.

Over that time, CISA has lost around one-third of its staff, which cost it programs, personnel, and expertise, including the agencyâ€™s counter-ransomware initiative and efforts to promote secure software development. Some of these haveincluded several members of its election security team, TechCrunch reported last year. CISA is the federal agency responsible for election security. Some warned that Trumpâ€™s ongoing obsession with promoting false claims about the 2020 election has led to the administration deprioritizing CISA.

CISAalsoreassignedhundreds of other staffersto aid other agencies within the Department of Homeland Security as part of the Trump administrationâ€™s broad immigration crackdown.

Many of Cyberscoopâ€™s sources blame the Trump administration, Congress, or both. Others singled out CISAâ€™s acting director, Madhu Gottumukkala, as having struggled to lead the agency and reportedly causedsecurity headachesas a result.

CISA has beenwithout a permanent directorsince Trump entered office in 2025.

The cybersecurity agency is said to be currently operatingat around 38% staff levelsas the partial U.S. federal government shutdown, which began on February 14, drags on. Lawmakers have declined to continue funding federal immigration authorities amid widespread criticism following the killing of two U.S. citizens by federal agents.

When reached for comment, CISAâ€™s Gottumukkala told TechCrunch that the agency â€œremains unwavering in its commitment to protect our federal networks from malicious cyber threat actors despite the multi-week government shutdownâ€ of Homeland Security.
articles.excerpt:
U.S. cybersecurity agencyCISAisreportedly in dire shape, according to bipartisan lawmakers and industry leaders who fear that the agencyâ€™s ability to perform its core mission has been diminished and left it unprepared for a cybersecurity crisis.

articles.title: Read AI launches a email based â€˜digital twinâ€™ to help you with schedules and answers
articles.author: Ivan Mehta
articles.content:
Meeting notetaker Read AI on Thursday launched an AI-powered email-based assistant called Ada, saying it helps users manage their schedules, answer questions based on a companyâ€™s knowledge base, and reply to out-of-office emails.

The company is calling Ada a â€œdigital twinâ€ that handles tasks for you around the clock. Read AI said that the assistant will be available to all users, and they can start configuring it by sending an email to â€œada@read.aiâ€ and writing â€œGet me started.â€

When you ask Ada to find a time to meet with someone, it replies to the other person in the thread with your availability. If the other person replies that they are unavailable at those times and would like a different time slot, Ada responds with new options. While Ada has access to your calendar through Read AI, it does not reveal the nature of those meetings with other people.

Ada can also answer questions using a companyâ€™s knowledge base, topics discussed in your prior meetings, and public internet searches. For instance, you can ask, â€œAda , can you provide an update on how we are tracking for Q1 goals?â€ to get information.

If someone else asks a question in a thread, Ada will prepare a response for you and help you refine it before it is sent to the other person. The startup said that Ada doesnâ€™t reveal any sensitive information without your permission.

Read AIâ€™s VP of Product, Justin Farris, said that the new feature doesnâ€™t rely on MCPs (Model Context Protocols, a technical standard for connecting AI tools to external services), and instead builds a knowledge graph based on meeting data and connected services for more contextual answers. He added that over time, the assistant will also take proactive actions for you. For instance, if you mentioned a follow-up item in a meeting, Ada will ask you to set that up after the meeting with contextual data.

â€œThe way I describe our solution is that when you are bringing on a new employee, you train them. When you add Ada to your workflow and connect more services to give more context, it starts to ramp up and handle more tasks for you,â€ CEO David Shim told TechCrunch.

The company said that while Ada, currently works via email, it will soon be available on Slack and Teams.

On the sidelines of Web Summit Qatar earlier this month, Shim told TechCrunch that the company now has over 5 million monthly active users and plans to grow that number to 10 million. He mentioned that the company sees 50,000 sign-ups every day and has a broader base of 100,000 users who consume Read AIâ€™s content, like meeting summaries, without creating an account.

For Read AI, the U.S. remains the largest market with strong international growth. While 60% of users are outside the U.S., the revenue is split roughly equally.

The company, which has raised over$81 million in funding, is increasingly adding AI-powered tools to its suite. Last year, it launchedSearch Copilotfor knowledge discovery for users, and last month, it added the ability to update customer-service relationship software, send a custom emails from within a meeting report, and stay up to date on topics basedon internal and web knowledge.

Other meeting notetakers are also offering new tools to extract more insights and actions from meeting notes. Last September, Granola addedâ€œrecipesâ€ in the form of repeatable promptsto surface knowledge from meeting data.Quill, which came out of stealth with a $6.5 million funding round this week, also connects to various tools like Linear, Notion, and CRMs, and aims to automate tasks.

articles.title: Bumble adds AI-powered photo feedback and profile guidance tools
articles.author: Amanda Silberling
articles.content:
Bumbleannouncedon Thursday that itâ€™s adding a series of AI-driven features intended to help turn matches into lasting connections, including those that offer feedback and guidance on usersâ€™ bios, photos, and prompts.

The dating appâ€™s new AI-suggested profile guidance tool will roll out globally and give â€œpersonalized, actionable feedbackâ€ on usersâ€™ bios and prompts. For users in the U.S., the profile guidance feature can be augmented with an AI photo feedback tool, which can â€œhelp you choose the best photos and show up as your most authentic self.â€

According to Bumbleâ€™s blog post explaining these features, it doesnâ€™t seem like the insights from these AI tools are particularly groundbreaking â€” for example, Bumble says that its AI photo tool might encourage you to ditch photos where youâ€™re wearing sunglasses that cover your face, and add a wider variety of photos, like ones taken outdoors or with friends. Itâ€™s advice you couldâ€™ve easily gotten from a friend ten years ago, but itâ€™s still new information to many users.

In Canada, Bumble is testing another, non-AI feature called â€œSuggest a Date.â€ When a conversation stalls, a user can signal that they are open to meeting in person, which the company says is â€œa simple way to signal that theyâ€™re ready to connect offline.â€

Of course, another way for people to â€œsignal that theyâ€™re ready to connect offlineâ€ is to literally ask someone on a date. But realistically, it doesnâ€™t seem like users are taking the plunge, so having an in-app way to indicate interest may motivate some potential couples to move their conversation IRL.

â€œWith Suggest a Date, weâ€™re creating a clear expression of intent and giving members a way to bypass the traditional back-and-forth and move toward meeting in real life,â€ Bumble CTO Vivek Sagi said in a statement. â€œWhen we reduce friction at the moments that matter most, we help people connect with clarity and confidence, and increase the likelihood of meaningful relationships forming offline.â€

Bumble and other popular dating apps, like Match Groupâ€™s Tinder and Hinge, have all embraced AI-powered features in recent months. For instance, in December, Hinge introduced a tool to help generate more interesting conversation starters than â€œHow are you?â€

Tinder may take things a step further. In Australia, Tinder is piloting a tool calledChemistry, which asks users to provide the app with access to their camera roll, which is a concerning amount of data to feed into an AI tool. Based on a userâ€™s camera roll and answers to a series of questions, the AI can learn more about someoneâ€™s interests and personality to supposedly reduce â€œswipe fatigueâ€ and suggest better matches.

Metaâ€™s Facebook Dating tool does something similar â€” in October, it launched a feature thatasks to use its AI on your camera rollthat you havenâ€™t yet shared in order to suggest AI edits.

As these companies try to come up with new ways to keep users happy, some young people have thrown in the towel on online dating altogether, instead seeking morereal-world experiencesthat are not intermediated by an app.
